Judge Neil Gorsuch expressed what he believed to be the expectations of a judge after President Trump named him his nominee to fill the vacant Supreme Court seat. USA TODAY NETWORK 

It was a cynical abdication of their constitutional duty when Republicans refused to give a hearing to President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, Judge Merrick Garland.
The judge nominated by President Trump to fill the seat stolen from Garland once referred to Judge Garland, along with the Supreme Court’s current Chief Justice John Roberts, as “widely considered to be among the finest lawyers of their generation.”
Trump's pick once lauded Garland Judge Neil Gorsuch speaks in the East Room of the White House in Washington, Tuesday, Jan. 31, 2017, after President Donald Trump announced Gorsuch as his nominee for the Supreme Court. (AP Photo/Carolyn Kaster)   (Photo: AP) 
Back in 2002 Trump's nominee Neil Gorsuch wrote an essay for a national news service lamenting the treatment of judges like Garland and Roberts who, Gorsuch said, didn't shy from difficult issues, adding, "both have litigated controversial cases involving ‘hot-button’ issues, for which their confirmations (to lower courts) had been delayed."
It was a very eloquent essay.
MORE: McCain, Flake praise Gorsuch 
Gorsuch wrote, "Today, there are too many who are concerned less with promoting the best public servants and more with enforcing litmus tests and locating unknown 'stealth candidates' who are perceived as likely to advance favored political causes once on the bench. Politicians and pressure groups on both sides declare that they will not support nominees unless they hew to their own partisan creeds. When a favored candidate is voted down for lack of sufficient political sympathy to those in control, grudges are held for years, and retaliation is guaranteed.”
Now, here sits Gorsuch, the beneficiary of politicians acting on “partisan creeds.”
How does he feel about that, I wonder?
Will he tell the senators at his confirmation hearing that Garland should have been given a hearing?
Jeez, GOP. Hypocrite much? CLOSE Skip in Skip x Embed

President Barack Obama announced that federal appeals court judge Merrick Garland as his nominee for the Supreme Court vacancy. USA TODAY 
There are Democrats who seem intent on making a stink over Gorsuch’s nomination.
Oregon Democratic Sen. Jeff Merkley said, "This is a stolen seat. This is the first time a Senate majority has stolen a seat. We will use every lever in our power to stop this."
I’m not sure they will, actually. Not enough of them, anyway. They could stall things if they want. Stage a filibuster. Require a super majority of 60 votes for confirmation.
Already Republicans are saying that such a thing would be doing a disservice to the process and to the Constitution.
MONTINI: Sen. Flake wanted to give Garland a hearing 
Please. 
Let’s not be too hypocritical.
Trump's nominee Gorsuch wrote, “When a favored candidate is voted down for lack of sufficient political sympathy to those in control, grudges are held for years, and retaliation is guaranteed.”
If only ethics matched ego If he genuinely believed what he wrote about the dangers of politicizing the judge-selection process Gorsuch would hold a press conference to say that he’d be honored if Trump were to make him his second nominee to the Supreme Court – after Garland.
He won’t, of course.
Ethics are no match for ego and ambition.
And as far as retaliation goes, Democrats should take the high road.
They should fulfill their constitutional duty, cooperate with a confirmation hearing for Gorsuch and take a vote – after 293 days.
Roughly 10 months. That’s how long Garland’s nomination was held up by Republicans , from March of last year until earlier this month. When his nomination -- and some of our Constitution's integrity -- expired.
